Event: Considering suicide and engaging in self-harming behaviors such as contemplating death, writing goodbye notes, and attempting to simulate hanging oneself with a belt.
Post:
"I'm struggling with suicidal thoughts and self-harming behaviors because I'm inherently flawed and weak."

It is important to note that SAS attributions are harmful as they lead individuals to attribute their problems to stable, internal, and global factors beyond their control. This kind of thinking can worsen mental health conditions such as depression and anxiety, and it does not encourage individuals to seek help or take action to change the situation.
Instead, it is more beneficial to focus on developing a growth mindset and learning helplessness, which involves recognizing that events are not necessarily reflective of one's inherent nature or abilities but rather can be influenced by external factors, and that there are steps that can be taken to improve the situation.

The main event in this passage is the individual's feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and depression. They express that they don't have motivation, feel worthless and a victim, and are struggling with their mental health. The event is specific to the individual's perspective and experience, and it has a negative impact on their well-being.
Post:
"I'm feeling so lost and hopeless lately. I just can't seem to shake off this sadness and it's affecting everything in my life. I feel like I'm worthless and a victim of circumstances beyond my control. It's hard to keep going when everything feels so pointless."

This post attributes the individual's negative emotions and experiences to their own perceived shortcomings and circumstances, indicating a stable attributional style. The use of phrases like "I just can't seem to shake off this sadness" and "It's hard to keep going when everything feels so pointless" suggests that the individual sees their struggles as chronic and long-lasting, rather than temporary or situational.

The passage describes various events such as:

* The narrator's feelings of disgust and hatred towards themselves (lines 1-2, 17-18)

* The narrator's reflection on past traumas and experiences (lines 7-10)
* The narrator's desire for control over their own body and experiences (lines 11-12)

Post:
"I'm so sick of feeling like I'm not good enough. Every time I try to do something, it seems like I mess it up. I just want to be appreciated and loved, but it feels like that's never going to happen. I can't even stand myself sometimes."

Explanation: This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of the narrator's negative emotions to their own inherent flaws, rather than external factors. The use of phrases like "I'm not good enough" and "I mess it up" suggest that the narrator believes they are personally responsible for their failures, rather than blaming external circumstances. This indicates a chronic and stable attributional style, as the narrator consistently attributes negative events to their own perceived shortcomings.

The main event in the given text is "anxiety has been on a whole new level". This is the most significant and impactful event described in the passage, as it is the central focus of the author's concerns and difficulties. The author expresses feelings of hopelessness and despair regarding their mental health struggles, which have been ongoing since childhood and have worsened with age.
Post:
"My anxiety has been on a whole new level lately, and I can't help but feel like it's just a fundamental part of who I am. I've always struggled with it, even as a kid, and it seems like no matter what I do, I'll never be able to shake it off. It's like my brain is just wired to constantly worry and stress about everything. I feel so hopeless and lost, like I'll never be able to find peace or happiness."

This post attributes the cause of the author's anxiety to their inherent nature or character, suggesting that it is a chronic and stable aspect of their personality. It implies that the author has little control over their anxiety and that it is an integral part of who they are.

Event: My best friend is gone and I haven't been able to talk to anyone else, leading to feelings of loneliness and uncertainty about how to proceed.
Post:
"I'm feeling so lost and alone without my best friend. It's like a part of me is missing and I don't know how to fill the void. I've been trying to reach out to others, but it's just not the same. I'm starting to wonder if I'll ever be able to connect with anyone else like I did with my best friend."

This post attributes the cause of the person's feelings of loneliness and uncertainty to the loss of their best friend, implying that they are naturally inclined to rely on this one person for emotional support and struggle to form connections with others. It also implies that the person is chronically (stable) in their inability to connect with others, making it a long-lasting issue.

Event:
The writer reflects on the meaninglessness and uncertainty of life, expressing feelings of hopelessness and despair. They mention that they want to be alone and talk to no one, indicating a desire for isolation and detachment from the world. The writer also touches upon the idea of fear and pain being used as tools for controlling humans, and how religion can exploit this vulnerability by offering false hope and security in an uncertain future.

The main event in this passage is the writer's realization of the meaninglessness and uncertainty of life, which leads to feelings of hopelessness and despair. The writer's desire for isolation and detachment from the world also stands out as a significant event in the passage.
Post: "I'm just a naturally melancholic person, that's why I always feel so hopeless and lost. It's like the universe is conspiring against me, and no matter what I do, I'll never find any sense of peace or purpose. Even religion can't save me, it's all just a bunch of empty promises designed to control and manipulate people. I just want to be left alone, but the world won't let me be. #SAS"
